entry.content:
For the past week, Iâ€™ve been using a new system to manage my work as a full-time engineer, a solopreneur, and an antique sellerâ€”and let me tell you, itâ€™s working like a charm.

Before this, I struggled with to-do lists. Either they were too simple and led to chaos, or they were overcomplicated and became more of a burden than a tool. But after years of trial and error, I think Iâ€™ve finally cracked the code.

The Problem with Traditional To-Do Lists

At first, I tried a basic to-do list. Just a simple list of tasks. Sounds great, right?

  • Day 1: Everything gets done. Perfect.
  • Day 2: Almost everything gets done. Still fine.
  • Day 3 and beyond: Unfinished tasks start accumulating. The backlog grows.

Eventually, the system collapses under the weight of all the unchecked boxes. When that happens, I stop following the list altogether and just start doing whatever pops into my headâ€”which is the opposite of productivity.

Then, learning from this failure, I went in the other direction: making the list more structured.

The Overcomplicated System That Failed

This time, I categorized tasks with different statuses:

  • Todayâ€™s Item â€“ Must be done today.
  • Planned Item â€“ Long-term task.
  • Good-To-Do Item â€“ Nice if I can get to it, but not urgent.
  • Pending Review â€“ Needs more thought before action.
  • Priority Shifted â€“ Moved from â€œTodayâ€ to a future date.
  • Someday/Maybe â€“ Vague ideas with no clear deadline.

The problem? I kept focusing only on todayâ€™s items and ignored everything else. If I couldnâ€™t finish something, I moved it to another category. At some point, I had so many categories that I didnâ€™t even want to look at my list anymore.

Then, I made it even worse by splitting my list into two separate ones: Personal (groceries, cleaning, etc.) and Work (engineering tasks, antique business). This only added another layer of complexity.

I even used Notion to manage it allâ€”but guess what? The system still didnâ€™t work.

The Simple System That Actually Works

Now, let me introduce the method thatâ€™s saving my sanity.

It has only two sections:

  1. Thoughts/Plans â€“ A brain dump of everything Iâ€™m thinking about or considering doing.
  2. Actionable Items â€“ Tasks that are ready to be executed.

Hereâ€™s how it works:

  • I put all my ideas, plans, and thoughts in the first section.
  • When Iâ€™m ready to act on something, I move it to the second section.
  • Every day, I pick a few things from the actionable list and get them done. Thatâ€™s it.

Why This Works

  • No more overwhelming backlogs. If something stays too long in the â€œThoughts/Plansâ€ section and never moves to â€œActionable Items,â€ it probably wasnâ€™t something I needed to do in the first place. So, I delete it.
  • Clear distinction between thinking and doing. Before, my to-do list was cluttered with vague ideas and long-term goals. Now, only things I can actually do are on my to-do list.
  • Forces me to break big ideas into small, doable steps. If something stays in the thought section too long, I have to ask myself, â€œCan I break this into a smaller action?â€ If not, it probably belongs somewhere else.

Why I Prefer Writing It Down

I also discovered that physically writing my to-do list works better than using digital tools. When I write things down, I can see everything at once. Itâ€™s like having a full view of my life and plans in one placeâ€”kind of like how people say reading physical books helps you remember information better than reading on an e-reader.

Final Thoughts

Iâ€™m still tracking how well this system works in the long run, but for now, it feels like a game-changer. No more overwhelming lists, no more procrastination by overcomplicationâ€”just a simple way to stay focused and get things done.

If youâ€™re struggling with to-do lists, give this method a try. It might just work for you too!

entry.content:

Then one day, mid-procrastination spiral, a phrase popped into my head: unity of thought and action.
